text: was a after Ninju and before Ten'an. This period started in November 854Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Ninju" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 716. and ended in February 857.Nussbaum, "Ten'an" at p. 957. During this time, the emperor was .Titsingh, Isaac. (1834). Annales des empereurs du japon, p. 112-114; Brown, Delmer et al. (1979). Gukanshō, p. 285; Varley, H. Paul. (1980). Jinnō Shōtōki, p. 165. ==Events of the Saikō era== * 21 April 854 (Saikō 1, 13th day of the 6th month): Minamoto no Tokiwa, also known as Minamoto no Tsune, died at age 43.Titsingh, p. 113; Brown, p. 285; Nussbaum, "Minamoto no Tokiwa" at p. 634. He was a son of Emperor Saga and he was one of the editors of the Nihon kōki.Nussbaum, "Nihon kōki" at p. 709. * 855 (Saikō 2, 1st month): An Emishi uprising in the north was met with military force.Titsingh, p. 114. * 855 (Saikō 2, 5th month): The head of the great statute of Buddha in the Tōdai-ji fell off. Donations were collected to pay for making another head for the Daibutsu. ==Related pages== * Heian period == References == == Other websites == * National Diet Library, "The Japanese Calendar" -- historical overview plus illustrative images from library's collection Saikō 1st 2nd 3rd 4th 854 855 856 857 Preceded by: Ninju Era or nengō: Saikō Succeeded by: Ten'an Category:Japanese eras Category:850s establishments in Japan Category:850s disestablishments in Japan Category:850s establishments
title: Saikō
